div.p: Due to the ubiquitous existence of external disturbances, the design of distributed control algorithms with robustness is an urgent demand for multi-agent system applications. This technical note investigates the robust distributed model predictive control (MPC) problem for a group of nonlinear agents (subsystems) subject to control input constraints and external disturbances. A robustness constraint is proposed to handle the external disturbances. Based on this, a novel robust distributed MPC scheme is designed for the overall agent system. Furthermore, the feasibility of the robust distributed MPC scheme and the robust stability of the overall agent system are analyzed, respectively. The conditions under which the proposed MPC is feasible and the overall agent system is robustly stabilized are established. Finally, the application of the robust distributed MPC to a group of cart-damper-spring systems verifies the theoretical results.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: This note considers the robust distributed model predictive control (MPC) problem of large-scale dynamically decoupled continuous-time nonlinear systems. It is motivated by application scenarios where a group of dynamically decoupled agents need to perform a cooperative task or achieve some coordination through a distributed manner. In such scenarios, the cooperation or coordination can be achieved through a centralized cost function. Yet, on the one hand, the implementation of the centralized MPC (such as [1], [2]) might be hindered due to its computational inefficiency and/or the unavailability of a centralized control structure; on the other hand, the decentralized MPC may result in poor performance because of ignoring couplings among agents [3]. Therefore, the distributed MPC is adopted to approximate the centralized objective by designing a local MPC associated with each agent and exchanging information among agents. This type of study finds many practical applications such as multi-vehicle formation control and cooperative tracking control [4]- [6].

In the literature on distributed MPC, some promising results have been reported for large-scale linear systems, nonlinear systems, and their applications; see the survey paper [7] and the references therein. In particular, the results closely related with this study are reviewed as follows. In [4], Dunbar and Murray develop a distributed MPC strategy to handle continuous-time decoupled nonlinear subsystems with coupled objective functions. Further, the discrete-time case is discussed in [6]. By considering the coupled term as a bounded disturbance, Franco et al. in [5] study the distributed MPC problem for discrete-time decoupled nonlinear agent systems with delayed information exchange. In addition, some application-oriented research has been reported. For instance, the distributed MPC is designed for the cooperative control of multiple vehicles with delays in [8]. In [9], the distributed MPC problem is investigated for a vehicle platoon to achieve leader-follower formation control. Note that these aforementioned results are developed without considering external disturbances to the system under study.

In practice, however, the system is inevitably subject to disturbances. How to design robust distributed MPC for decoupled nonlinear systems with disturbances remains open. This motivates us to develop a robust distributed MPC scheme that can accommodate external disturbances. It is worth noting that, in [10], the robust distributed MPC problem is investigated for decoupled linear subsystems subject to external disturbances and coupled input constraints. This note focuses on the robust distributed MPC design for general continuous-time decoupled nonlinear subsystems subject to energy-bounded disturbances and control input constraints. The coupling caused by the centralized objective is incorporated into the distributed cost functions. This study extends the framework in [4] in terms of incorporating the disturbances into the analysis and synthesis, and therefore, the proposed distributed MPC design can accommodate the ubiquitous system noise or modeling errors.

It has been pointed out in [11] that, the conventional MPC may not be robust against external disturbances, and the closed-loop system might be destabilized even for small perturbations. In order to design a distributed MPC framework which will be robust against the external disturbances, a novel strategy called robustness constraint is proposed in this note. In addition, a robust dual-mode distributed MPC scheme is designed, and the conditions of guaranteeing the feasibility of the designed distributed MPC and the stability of the overall system are established. It is shown that, the stability conditions of the overall large-scale system are essentially related to the bound of external disturbances, the sampling period and the cooperation matrices. The overall large-scale system is proven to converge to an invariant set under the established conditions.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: We investigate the robust distributed MPC problem for a group of decoupled constrained nonlinear agent systems with external disturbances. By introducing a robustness constraint, we design a new robust dual-mode distributed MPC scheme that can deal with bounded external disturbances. Based on the triangle inequality and the Gronwall-Bellman inequality, it has been proven that the feasibility of the robust dual-mode distributed MPC can be guaranteed if the sampling period is appropriately chosen according to the established condition and the external disturbances are bounded by some critical values. Furthermore, it has been shown that, the overall agent system can be stabilized into a robust invariant set, provided that the sampling period, the disturbances and the cooperation matrices satisfy the designed conditions.
